mn139:0.1_0: For the middle part of the night,
mn139:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn139:10.10_0: ‘Don’t talk behind people’s backs, and don’t speak sharply in their presence.’
mn139:10.11_0: That's why I said what I said.
mn139:10.1_0: ‘Don’t talk behind people’s backs, and don’t speak sharply in their presence.’
mn139:10.3_0: And what did I say about this?
mn139:10.4_0: When you know that what you say behind someone’s back is untrue, false, and harmful, then if at all possible you should not speak.
mn139:10.5_0: When you know that what you say behind someone’s back is true and correct, but harmful, then you should train yourself not to speak.
mn139:10.6_0: When you know that what you say behind someone’s back is true, correct, and beneficial, then you should know the right time to speak.
mn139:10.7_0: When you know that your sharp words in someone’s presence are untrue, false, and harmful, then if at all possible you should not speak.
mn139:10.8_0: When you know that your sharp words in someone’s presence are true and correct, but harmful, then you should train yourself not to speak.
mn139:10.9_0: When you know that your sharp words in someone’s presence are true, correct, and beneficial, then you should know the right time to speak.
mn139:11.2_0: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
mn139:11.3_0: When speaking hurriedly, your body gets tired, your mind gets stressed, your voice gets stressed, your throat gets sore, and your words become unclear and hard to understand.
mn139:11.4_0: When not speaking hurriedly, your body doesn’t get tired, your mind doesn’t get stressed, your voice doesn’t get stressed, your throat doesn’t get sore, and your words are clear and easy to understand.
mn139:11.6_0: That's why I said what I said.
mn139:12.10_0: And however it is known in those various localities, you speak accordingly, thinking: ‘It seems that the venerables are referring to this.’
mn139:12.11_0: That’s how you don’t insist on local terminology and don’t override normal usage.
mn139:12.12_0: ‘Don’t insist on local terminology and don’t override normal usage.’
mn139:12.13_0: That's why I said what I said.
mn139:12.1_0: ‘Don’t insist on local terminology and don’t override normal usage.’
mn139:12.2_0: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
mn139:12.3_0: And how do you insist on local terminology and override normal usage?
mn139:12.4_0: It’s when in different localities the same thing is known as a ‘plate’, a ‘bowl’, a ‘cup’, a ‘dish’, a ‘basin’, a ‘tureen’, or a ‘porringer’.
mn139:12.5_0: And however it is known in those various localities, you speak accordingly, obstinately sticking to that and insisting:
mn139:12.6_0: ‘This is the only truth, other ideas are silly.’
mn139:12.7_0: That’s how you insist on local terminology and override normal usage.
mn139:12.8_0: And how do you not insist on local terminology and not override normal usage?
mn139:12.9_0: It’s when in different localities the same thing is known as a ‘plate’, a ‘bowl’, a ‘cup’, a ‘dish’, a ‘basin’, a ‘tureen’, or a ‘porringer’.
mn139:13.10_0: Breaking off such indulgence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.
mn139:13.13_0: The middle way of practice by which the Realized One was awakened gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment. It is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.
mn139:13.16_0: Flattering and rebuking without teaching Dhamma is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.
mn139:13.19_0: Neither flattering nor rebuking, and just teaching Dhamma is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.
mn139:13.1_0: Now, mendicants, pleasure linked to sensuality is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. Indulging in such happiness is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.
mn139:13.22_0: Sensual pleasure—a filthy, common, ignoble pleasure—is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.
mn139:13.25_0: The pleasure of renunciation, the pleasure of seclusion, the pleasure of peace, the pleasure of awakening is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.
mn139:13.28_0: Saying untrue, false, and harmful things behind someone’s back is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.
mn139:13.31_0: Saying true and correct, but harmful things behind someone’s back is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.
mn139:13.34_0: Saying true, correct, and beneficial things behind someone’s back is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.
mn139:13.37_0: Saying untrue, false, and harmful things in someone’s presence is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.
mn139:13.40_0: Saying true and correct, but harmful things in someone’s presence is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.
mn139:13.43_0: Saying true, correct, and beneficial things in someone’s presence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.
mn139:13.46_0: Speaking hurriedly is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.
mn139:13.49_0: Speaking unhurriedly is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.
mn139:13.4_0: Breaking off such indulgence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.
mn139:13.52_0: Insisting on local terminology and overriding normal usage is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.
mn139:13.55_0: Not insisting on local terminology and not overriding normal usage is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.
mn139:13.7_0: Indulging in self-mortification is painful, ignoble, and pointless. It is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.
mn139:14.1_0: So you should train like this: ‘We shall know the principles beset by conflict and the principles free of conflict.
mn139:14.2_0: Knowing this, we will practice the way free of conflict.’
mn139:14.3_0: And, mendicants, Subhūti, the gentleman, practices the way of non-conflict.”
mn139:14.4_0: This is what the Buddha said.
mn139:14.5_0: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.
mn139:14.6_0: The ninth section on the analysis of non-conflict is finished.
mn139:2.1_0: “Mendicants, I shall teach you the analysis of non-conflict.
mn139:2.2_0: listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
mn139:3.10_0: This is the recitation passage for the analysis of non-conflict.
mn139:3.1_0: “Don’t indulge in sensual pleasures, which are low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. And don’t indulge in self-mortification, which is painful, ignoble, and pointless.
mn139:3.2_0: Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One woke up by understanding the middle way of practice, which gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.
mn139:3.3_0: Know what it means to flatter and to rebuke.
mn139:3.4_0: Knowing these, avoid them, and just teach Dhamma.
mn139:3.5_0: Know how to assess different kinds of pleasure.
mn139:3.7_0: Don’t talk behind people’s backs, and don’t speak sharply in their presence.
mn139:3.9_0: Don’t insist on local terminology and don’t override normal usage.

mn139:9.10_0: touches known by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
mn139:9.11_0: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
mn139:9.12_0: The pleasure and happiness that arise from these five kinds of sensual stimulation is called sensual pleasure—a filthy, common, ignoble pleasure.
mn139:9.13_0: Such pleasure should not be cultivated or developed, but should be feared, I say.
mn139:9.14_0: Now, take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
mn139:9.15_0: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption ...
mn139:9.17_0: enters and remains in the fourth absorption.
mn139:9.18_0: This is called the pleasure of renunciation, the pleasure of seclusion, the pleasure of peace, the pleasure of awakening.
mn139:9.19_0: Such pleasure should be cultivated and developed, and should not be feared, I say.
